awd_abstract_narration:
This award will establish a Marine Genomics Center at the University of Washington’s Friday Harbor Laboratories (FHL) by remodeling an underutilized lab building, already equipped with a flow-through seawater system, into a wet lab with dry procedure spaces containing the modern tools for molecular genomics – tools for nanopore sequencing, amplification, purification, and quality assurance. The new lab will attract new researchers, will allow established researchers to expand their work at FHL, and will be used as a training center for the next generation of biologists participating in FHL programs involving genomics research. Having the lab configuration easily modified will also enable its use for
short-term training workshops with 15-20 participants. 

This Center will contribute to research on understanding the relationship between organismal genomes and phenomes. A lab with the capacity for DNA barcoding, whole genome sequencing, real time PCR, and disease detection will significantly expand on FHL’s existing strengths in bioimaging, libraries of CT scans, apprenticeships, workshops, and undergraduate training programs in phenomics research. An onsite molecular biology lab at FHL will attract new principal investigators and graduate students and maintain its relevance as a research institution. Investing in infrastructure for molecular biology research at FHL will have broader impacts in human health and will help communicate the connections between molecules, organismal morphology, and the ocean. For more information about Friday Harbor Laboratories, see https://fhl.uw.edu/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Washington’s marine lab, Friday Harbor Laboratories (FHL), used NSF funding to convert an old (built in 1925), underutilized lab building, with electrical system and furnishings badly in need of renovation, to a clean, dry, and modern Marine Genomics Center with cutting-edge equipment for molecular research. Most of the extensive renovation was accomplished by FHL’s Maintenance team, thus avoiding the cost overruns that plague such projects when there is a heavy reliance on outside contractors. The FHL Marine Genomics Center, which opened in June 2024, has modern tools including those for nanopore sequencing, PCR amplification, nucleic acid purification, and quality assurance. The remodeled lab building is ADA accessible, and the space has mobile workspaces so that it can be reconfigured for research, teaching, or workshop space as needed. Campus-wide, FHL research space is well balanced with teaching space, but we had no place to hold hands-on research workshops for 15-20 participants. We published a recent Tide Bite, advertising the new lab to the general public and FHL researchers: fhl.uw.edu/about/news-and-events/2024/09/24/tide-bite-october-2024/

 

FHL courses and workshops, especially the intense, 3-5 week summer sessions that are geared towards graduate students and advanced undergraduates, serve as critical training grounds for students to learn tools and techniques within their fields. In most summers FHL offers two to four courses that will take advantage of new genomics equipment in their curricula, exposing 15-20 students per course to the intellectual power of these tools as well as practical aspects of their use. In Summer 2024, the new Genomics Center was used by summer students in a course designed specifically to use the facility: “Functional Biodiversity: Exploring Origins of the Brain in Marine Invertebrate Larvae”; this intensive 5-week class used the new equipment and attracted notable speakers from around and outside the US to explore marine invertebrate biodiversity using genetic tools to investigate biological functions and their underlying mechanisms. The space was also used by summer NSF-REU students and their mentors, and by visiting and resident researchers. We anticipate that ongoing advertising of this facility and its available equipment will attract a broader swath of mentors for our NSF REU site program as well as instructors for new courses and workshops. This facility also is an important tool in our efforts to attract new principal investigators and graduate students by filling a technological gap. Furthermore, our station has handicapped accessible housing, has hosted differently abled students and faculty - but this is our first wet-lab space that is accessible to people with mobility challenges. Nationwide, wet lab space accessible to reduced mobility scientists is rare, a serious shortcoming addressed by this renovation. Ultimately, the Genomics Center contributes to the infrastructure of the university by increasing the research capacity of its marine lab. Field stations are important for research and teaching, but the relevance of field stations at an R1 institution is driven by research. Therefore, the most important thing our marine station can do to maintain relevance is attract a critical mass of high performing researchers.

In addition to attracting researchers and graduate students from around the globe, FHL uses diverse outreach methods for communicating science to K12 students and the general public. The new center will be featured at our annual Open House (May of each year), which attracts more than 500 members of the public (including many children) to tour the labs and learn about the science we do. Our 20-year-old Science Outreach program brings local students in all grades (>500 each year) to tour the facility and consider participation in our mentored programs. In an era when molecular biology is pointed straight at issues of human health, it is transformative to show young people the connections between molecules, organismal morphology, and the ocean.
